agar near the narrowed end. ,he agar melts and moves into the free end of the tube.
On cooling, the agar, in many cases, remains in the opening of the tube. The tube
is held on the side of the dish with a bit of clay and a defined eg; region is moved
into contact with the dye. The egg should be kept in contact with the dye until it
is visibly stained (1-5 minutes). Mark a number of eggs at the site of initiation
of the first cleavage; follow these eggs to see where the mark is in the embryos at
various developmental stages and in the planula. As an internal control, mark a
set of eggs opposite the site of polar body formation.
3) The induction of metamorphosis:
Metamorphosis in Hydractinia is normally induced when the planula comes in
contact with certain marine bacteria (Muller, W. 1973). Metamorphsis can also be
induced in these animals by treating them with certain ions for a short period of
time; a pulse type application of caesium is especially effective in inducing meta-
morphosis. A solution containing 9.76 3 CsCl/ 100 nl distilled water is mixed with
sea water to give a lzlo dilution. Three day old larvae are transferred to this
mixture and incubated for 3 hours. The incubation medium is then replaced with
normal sea water (several changes).
This metamor hosis induction system can be used to ask a number of uestions:

1) Are all parts of a nlanula competent to under netanor hosis? 2) What is the
I 1 
developmental potential o; different planula parts? One way in which this problem
can be approached is by cutting planulae into anterior, middle and posterior thirds.
Each third can then be treated with CaCl and the ability of each part to respond
to the inductor by settling and the differentiation of the cases that settle can be
scored.
Bibliography

Biol. Bull. 82:329-339.
Freeman, G. 1980 The role of cleavage in the establishment of the anterior-posterior
axis of the hydrozoan embryo LE: Developmental and Cellular Biology of Coelenterates
(P. and R. Tardent eds.) pp.97-108. Elsevier/North Holland, Amsterdam.
Freeman, G. 1981 The role of polarity in the development of hydrozoan planula larvae.
W. Roux's Arch. 190:168-184.
Miller, R. 1979 Sperm chemotaxis'in the hydromedusae I. Species-specificity and sperm
behavior. Mar. Biol. 53:97-lle.
Muller, W. 1973 Metamorphose-Induktion bei Planulalarven I. Der Bakterielle Induktor.
W. Roux's Arch. 1732107-l2l. 
Muller, W., Mitze, A., Wickhorst, J., and Meir-Menge, H. 1977 Polar morphogenesis in
early hydroid development: action of caesium, of neurotransmitters and of an
intrinsic head activator on pattern formation. W. Roux's Arch. 182:311-328.
Teissier, G. 1931 Etude experimentale du developpement de quelques hydraires. Ann.
Sci. Nat. Ser. Bot.et Zool. 14:5-60.
Teissier, L., and Teissier, G. 1927 Les principales etapes du developpment 
Hydractinia echinata Bull. Soc. Zool. Fr. 51:537-567.
